subject: Re: [junit] Re: testXXXX must return void?
msgSnippet: ... No argument against it. ... I ve done it and moved on; there s no need for me to re-live it. I ve already gone through what you re going through, learned
messageBody:
>So said areider on 2003-06-25 --------------------
>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
>wrote:
>
>> The whole point of JUnit is automate those tests so that you do not
>have to physically look at the result to verify it. You code what you
>expect in the test and the test runner tells you whether the results
>match your expectations. This is in perfect alignment with the
>purpose of JUnit.
>
>That is a good thing but there is more than one way to think about
>it.

No argument against it.

>> There are many reasons to write tests this way. I suggest reading
>the available literature, especially Kent Beck's Test-Driven
>Development by Example, http://www.xprogramming.com and
>http://www.junit.org
>
>Thanks, maybe you should do some more reading too and listen to other
>developers to expand your perspective to include viewpoints other
>than your own.

I've done it and moved on; there's no need for me to re-live it. I've already gone through what you're going through, learned from it and got to where I am today. If that stops working for me, then I'll move on.

Please don't assume that because my opinion is different from yours that that means that I don't completely understand your opinion. In this case, "been there; done that."

>> If JUnit wastes your time,
>
>word twisting, never said that.

I believe you said that JUnit forces you to duplicate your tests. How is that not a waste of time? And what about my suggestion for dealing with that duplication? Did you decide it wouldn't help?

>>If you think JUnit is beneficial,
>
>I do, and as I indicated I have plenty of experience with automated
>testing using xUnit.
>
>>then you have to change your approach to work with JUnit. If you
>want to do something slightly different than JUnit, then you have to
>find that or build it yourself.
>>
>> I think those are your options.
>
>How about just hacking junit? Make it do something the designers
>never intended. That's another option.

If you want to fork JUnit to a new project, no-one will stop you. I'm not sure what the difference is between "hacking JUnit" and building something for yourself, though. No-one said you had to build from scratch.

If you're interested in discussing the issues, that's fine. If you're going to allow yourself to be sidetracked by arguing about my motives, then please direct your energy elsewhere. I'm not interested in discussing that.
